Award.AwardTitle: AF: Small: Counting and Sampling Cuts and Paths in Planar and Lattice Graphs

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
This award targets counting and sampling variants of a number of cut and path problems in several restricted graph classes including planar graphs, the 8-connected 2D grid, and the 3D grid. These graph classes are primarily motivated by applications in computer vision where several recent results renewed interest in the minimization variants of these problems. The importance of the corresponding counting and sampling variants stems from, among others, automated learning of the parameters of the underlying probabilistic models such as the Markov Random Field.

The proposed research builds on the PI's recent works on counting and sampling minimum (s,t)-cuts and minimum single-source-multi-sink cuts with connectivity priors, both in planar graphs. These problems are used in image segmentation applications and form an initial step towards the ultimate goal of computing the partition function for weighted cuts, i.e., the summation of the cut weights across all (s,t)-cuts; this quantity is essential for model parameter learning via the maximum likelihood principle. The PI will study a variety of cut and path problems that generalize the initial results from different perspectives. These include studying other connectivity priors, moving beyond planarity, and beyond minimum cuts and shortest paths.

The research will actively involve undergraduate and master students. Related educational materials are projected to annually impact over 600 students, about 10 of them from the National Technical Institute for the Deaf. In addition to standard dissemination venues like conferences and journals, the PI will also present the results at the annual Imagine RIT festival. This community outreach festival attracted about 35,000 visitors in 2012, many of them middle and high school students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project aimed to design algorithms for counting various types of cuts and paths in planar graphs and other graphs of restricted structure. Among the applications of such counting problems is, for example, image segmentation in computer vision. The boundary of an object corresponds to a cycle in the dual graph of the grid graph that represents the image, and dual cycles correspond to cuts in the original grid graph. Counting, and the related concept of sampling, can be used to statistically analyze the images. An additional aspect of the project involved studying various closely related problems in statistical physics, such as counting independent sets.

 

The project led to several new algorithms as well as new hardness results when one proves that an algorithm is unlikely to exist. The findings have been disseminated via peer-reviewed publications and research talks. Among the most notable results are several joint works with undergraduate students. One set of works designed algorithms for cuts which satisfy connectivity requirements: As an example, for objects with thin parts, such as an insect with thin legs, a common issue with cut-based segmentation algorithms is that they sever the thin parts, leaving only the main part of the object. This can be remedied by forcing the algorithm to include the thin parts in the segmentation. Then, the algorithm does not look for the smallest cut but for a cut which connects all the required parts.

 

Another joint work with an undergraduate student resulted in the design of path-counting oracles, which can aid in fast computation of the number of minimum cuts. Other results of interest deal with counting all independent sets in a various types of graphs, where the weight of each independent set depends on its size.

 

The project involved a significant number of student collaborators of all academic levels: undergraduate, MS, and PhD. Six undergraduate students were supported by this award through NSF's Research Experience for Undergraduates supplementary funding. Additionally, the PI advised and continues to advise a number of related MS projects and theses. In the last term the project also supported one PhD student. The students worked on both theoretical algorithm design, as well on experimental evaluation of the designed algorithms and their applicability in real-world scenarios. Of all the students involved, several opted to pursue PhD studies and others are planning to apply to PhD programs in the near future. This training benefits the society in a number of ways: First, exposing students to research projects broadens their horizons in industry, where they can apply their newly gained critical thinking skills. If they choose to further their studies, they may become researchers in the field, pushing the boundaries of our current knowledge. And/or they may choose to work at academic institutions, educating future generations of students in STEM, and, in particular, in computer science, where the current enrollments indicate dire need for additional computer science faculty members.

 

An important part of the project was outreach: The students prepared and presented several well-received exhibits about their work at ImagineRIT, an annual outreach festival that showcases the work of RIT students, faculty, and staff to the broader community. The festival attracts over 30,000 visitors each year, many of whom are middle and high school students. The audience at this project's exhibits ranged from early grades in primary school through late adulthood, and come from a variety of backgrounds. The students outlined mathematical and algorithmic foundations of the research they worked on, and they ran simulations on real data that drew the children's (and nonexpert) interest that smoothly transitioned into discussions about some of the mathematical underpinnings of the work.
